issue.title: Potential Solution for Peacock Ads

labels.name: A: In progress
labels.description: Work on the issue is in progress

labels.name: A: Waiting for data
labels.description: Waiting for more information from the user

issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

Ads have recently started making their way through Peacock, and seem to have been for many users.

### Proposed solution

The following rules have successfully blocked all ads on Peacock (so far):
```
||g*-vod-us-cmaf-prd-*.cdn.peacocktv.com  # blocks all ads
@@||g*-vod-us-cmaf-prd-mc.cdn.peacocktv.com  # seems to allow the main content to come through.
```

Would love some feedback on if this works for anyone else.

### Additional information

Thanks to [this list of domains](https://gist.github.com/ozankiratli/801ba17705e7f2a904d2e443af5a64f8#peacock) curated by @ozankiratli as the base of this solution.

issue.title: Give users more control over the google search ai overview
issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

I deeply appreciate the effort you put into blocking the AI overview in google search. However, simply put it within the other annoyances filter seems a bit too straight forward. After all, I don't think this is as "bad" or "annoying" as the popups for website logins.


### Proposed solution

Would it be possible to provide a better control of this that allows the user to just turn this on/off without sacrificing all other cool blocks within the other annoyances filter?

Thanks!


### Additional information

_No response_

comment.body: Splitting the Annoyances lists further can be a solution or at least mitigation for this. I proposed splitting the all-in-one Annoyances filter in Slack, you know, as the list was just unusable to me. It was a big improvement that the list was splitted into the current 5 sublists, but I have no idea how it was determined and I'm only using the Cookie and Mobile app lists. The popup filter and Other Annoyances filter are already modulated in some files, what are the problems if you are to further split them?

issue.title: First party tracking script + tracking subdomains
issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

Many websites are using common first party tracking script.

### Proposed solution

Some examples..

At `clearstem.com`,
lftce.clearstem.com/load

fromourplace.com
oorto.fromourplace.com/load

philosophy.com
qphil.philosophy.com/providers/atLabel/load

lapolicegear.com
hbpvm.lapolicegear.com/providers/atLabel/load

I suggest adding these rules. Not all the scripts start with `/providers/`, so I added a second general rule. It should block all these here without needing to add any other domains.

`/providers/atLabel/load`
`/init?*fallbackUserId=*^pageUrl=`
`||customers.edgetag.io^` CNAME, should be found in first two
`||fallback.attntags.com^` CNAME, fallback if blocked

<details><summary>Screenshot</summary>

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/26c46cb4-10ce-4524-8745-81d43cc30feb)

</details>

issue.title: Strip out the ref URL search parameter
issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

I use the AdGuard URL Tracking Protection list via uBlock but I've noticed that it doesn't strip out the `ref` URL search parameter by default. The list strips it out on specific domains only (see for example specific.txt at [L22](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/TrackParamFilter/sections/specific.txt#L22), [L47](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/TrackParamFilter/sections/specific.txt#L47), etc.)

Is this intended? Have you noticed that stripping out `ref` by default breaks too many websites? I've tried to find issues or docs about this but couldn't (expected to see it under [Limitations](https://adguard.com/kb/general/ad-filtering/filter-policy/#limitations-and-exceptions-1) of tracking protection).

### Proposed solution

`*$removeparam=ref`

### Additional information

_No response_

comment.body:
@Yuki2718 I have it in my personal list, as mentioned above, but this isn't the point.

The purpose of hosted lists like AdGuard URL Tracking Protection is to help users prevent URL tracking _without_ them having to maintain personal lists. As a user, I'd like to be able to trust the list to protect me against URL tracking. However, many websites use `ref` in URLs in the same way they use `utm_source`, and the fact that AdGuard doesn't strip it out is going against the best interest of its users.

I believe that stripping out `ref` and whitelisting cases where it's used as necessary functionality is more maintainable and privacy-friendly that just ignoring the parameter. I understand it's a "risky" change, but anything that breaks will be reported and can be whitelisted—isn't this better than failing to remove a [well-known](https://docs.simpleanalytics.com/how-to-use-url-parameters) tracking parameter?

That being said, if you're not willing to consider this, I'll be happy to report websites that use `ref` for URL tracking, so they can be blocked on a domain-by-domain basis. It just seems like the wrong way to do things.

issue.title: www.youtube.com

labels.name: T: Anti Adblock Script
labels.description: The site detects ad blocking

labels.name: A: Problematic
labels.description: Issues, which cannot be resolved easily

issue.body:
# ATTENTION

> [!NOTE]  
> YouTube changes their detection scripts regularly. That means that sometime you can face the detection message.
> If all the following instructions do not work, please **email filters@adguard.com** or wait until any update is available. 

> [!CAUTION] 
> Please do not use another adblocker in the same time because using another adblocker can delay/lags the YouTube loading (e.g., AdBlock Plus and AdBlock)[^1] OR interfere AdGuard's filtering functionality.

> [!CAUTION] 
> Please do not use an userscript related to the bypassing YouTube detection message like [TheRealJoelmatic/RemoveAdblockThing](https://github.com/TheRealJoelmatic/RemoveAdblockThing).
> Recently, YouTube anti-adblock script added infinite dummy advertisements to try to neutralize the userscript. ( [TheRealJoelmatic/RemoveAdblockThing#264](https://github.com/TheRealJoelmatic/RemoveAdblockThing/issues/264) )

> [!WARNING]
> Please check that there no another web browser extension that has adblocking feature is enabled on your web browser. It can interfere AdGuard's filtering functionality.

> [!IMPORTANT]  
> Saving memory feature of your web browser or sleep feature of your operating system can interfere AdGuard's filtering functionality.
> In this case, please re-enable AdGuard's filtering by toggling the protection toggle.
> Following the instructions can be needed.

### The instructions
1. Force to update the filters by clicking the reload button in AdGuard Browser Extension/AdGuard mobile or update tray menu in your system tray. [^2]
2. Reload the YouTube webpage without cache by pressing <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> + <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>R</kbd> [^3].
3. Clear cache, cookies and site data of your web browser.
4. Re-open your web browser completely (checking your system monitor[^4] will be better).

[^1]: https://gitlab.com/adblockinc/ext/adblockplus/adblockplusui/-/issues/1576
[^2]: [AdGuard for Windows](https://adguard.com/kb/adguard-for-windows/overview/#tray-menu); [AdGuard for Mac](https://adguard.com/kb/adguard-for-mac/overview/#updates-check); 
[^3]: On macOS, <kbd>Command</kbd> + <kbd>Shift</kbd> + <kbd>R</kbd>
[^4]: Task Manager on Windows, System Monitor on GNOME Shell, KDE System Guard on KDE Plasma or Activity Monitor on macOS. 


Previous issue https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/issues/198973

issue.title: Give users more control over the google search ai overview
issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

I deeply appreciate the effort you put into blocking the AI overview in google search. However, simply put it within the other annoyances filter seems a bit too straight forward. After all, I don't think this is as "bad" or "annoying" as the popups for website logins.


### Proposed solution

Would it be possible to provide a better control of this that allows the user to just turn this on/off without sacrificing all other cool blocks within the other annoyances filter?

Thanks!


### Additional information

_No response_

comment.body:
> The name of this filter already suggests that it can block things that are not included in other categories. 

A problems is nobody knows if something will be classified into annoyances or not beforehand. It may be annoyances for some people, and be useful content for other people.

issue.title: Give users more control over the google search ai overview
issue.body:
### Prerequisites

- [x] I checked the documentation and found no answer;
- [x] I checked to make sure that this issue has not already been filed;
- [x] This is not an ad/bug report.

### Problem description

I deeply appreciate the effort you put into blocking the AI overview in google search. However, simply put it within the other annoyances filter seems a bit too straight forward. After all, I don't think this is as "bad" or "annoying" as the popups for website logins.


### Proposed solution

Would it be possible to provide a better control of this that allows the user to just turn this on/off without sacrificing all other cool blocks within the other annoyances filter?

Thanks!


### Additional information

_No response_

comment.body:
> what are the problems if you are to further split them?

Most users do not read filter descriptions. The name of this filter already suggests that it can block things that are not included in other categories. If you don't like the result, you can simply turn it off.
Increasing the number of filters will not solve the problem.

This issue has been automatically marked as stale because it has been open for 4 days with no activity.
Unfortunately, our resources are limited and we can not always take the time to respond to requests about websites that are not popular enough. The issue will be closed if no further activity occurs.
Please note, that AdGuard Filters is an open-source project that is used by different content blockers and we welcome contributions. If you have some technical knowledge about how websites work, you are welcome to create a pull request following [these instructions](https://github.com/AdguardTeam/AdguardFilters/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md).
